newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korean president shuffles aides to escape crisis.
newsitem.headline: S.Korean president shuffles aides to escape crisis.

text.p: South Korean president Kim Young-sam on Friday replaced his top aides, kicking off a sweeping administration reshuffle designed to restore his credibility following a loans scandal.
Kim dropped his chief secretary and three other top advisers responsible for political, economic and general affairs, a presidential spokesman said.
"This is the start of a major reshuffle in the government and the ruling party," he said. "The cabinet reshuffle is expected early next week."
Kim Yong-tae, a former home affairs minister who served four terms in parliament, would succeed Kim Kwang-il as chief of staff at the presidential Blue House.

All members of Kim Young-sam's Blue House inner circle, the entire cabinet and ruling New Korea Party leaders had offered to step down after the president apologised publicly on Tuesday over a loans-for-kickbacks scandal.
Kim Young-sam took ultimate responsibility for the scandal around the failed Hanbo Steel Co although he was not accused of any personal wrongdoing.

The chief Blue House political officer, Lee Won-jong, was replaced by Kang In-sop, a former member of parliament and an ex-journalist. His counterpart in charge of economic affairs, Lee Suk-chae, stepped down in favour of Kim In-ho, currently head of the Fair Trade Commission.
Under South Korea's presidential system, in which power is concentrated in the Blue House, Kim's aides have wielded great influence over policy.

Political analysts said the president appeared to be fighting to regain his political credibility and avoid being labelled a lame duck during his last year in office. The Hanbo scandal underlined the failure of President Kim's much-vaunted anti-corruption drive, and he promised on Tuesday to heed criticism that his close associates were incapable of carrying through reforms.
Prosecutors said banks, under pressure from politicians, offered huge loans in return for kickbacks from Hanbo, which racked up $5.8 billion in debts before going bankrupt on January 23.
